Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) governed by the differential equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), where A and B are constant matrices. We analyze the effect of the transformation \\( f(z) = e^{Ct}z \\) applied over time t, with C being another constant matrix.

If \\( f(z) \\) is applied to a complex number \\( z_0 = x_0 + iy_0 \\) at t = 0 and then allowed to evolve under the given differential equations without further intervention, will \\( z(T) \\) at t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved to t = T without the application of \\( f(z) \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( f(z) = e^{Ct}z \\) at t = 0 modifies both x and y components of z, thus altering the trajectory from the initial conditions. Since C can affect each component differently, this typically leads to a distinct endpoint at time T.
